questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText: Elements present in the same group are having similar chemical and physical properties. Why is it so?
questions.solutionContent: The chemical and physical properties of any elements depend on the quantity of valence electrons. Elements in the same group in the periodic table have the same quantity of valence electrons. This is why elements present in the same group have similar chemical and physical properties.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.8: Elements present in the same group are having similar chemical and physical properties. Why is it so?... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText: What do you understand by the term ‘Ionic radius’ and ‘atomic radius’?
questions.solutionContent:
Atomic radius: This is the radius of an atom, which quantifies its size. If the element is a metal, its radius is termed metallic radius. If it's a non-metal, its radius is termed covalent radius.
Metallic radius can be calculated as half the inter-nuclear distance between two adjacent metal atoms in a solid. For instance, for solid copper, if the inter-nuclear distance is 256 pm, the metallic radius of copper is 256/2 pm = 128 pm.
Covalent radius is measured as half the interatomic distance between two atoms when they are held together by a single bond in a covalent molecule. For example, if the interatomic distance between two chlorine atoms in a chlorine molecule is 198 pm, the covalent radius of chlorine is 198/2 pm = 99 pm.

Ionic radius: This is the radius of an ion (cation or anion). It is computed by measuring the inter-ionic distance between a cation and an anion in an ionic crystal.
Cations are formed by expelling an electron from the outermost orbit of an atom, resulting in fewer electrons compared to the parent atom. This leads to an increased effective nuclear charge. Thus, a cation is smaller in size than its parent atom. For example, the ionic radius of Na+ is 95 pm, while the atomic radius of Na is 186 pm.
Anions are formed by gaining an electron, meaning they have more electrons compared to the parent atom but the same nuclear charge. This results in increased repulsion among electrons within the atom and a decreased effective nuclear charge. Consequently, an anion is bigger in size than its parent atom. For example, the ionic radius of F− is 136 pm, while the atomic radius of F is 64 pm.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.9: What do you understand by the term ‘Ionic radius’ and ‘atomic radius’?... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText: Explain why there is variation in atomic radius in a group and period?
questions.solutionContent:
Across a period (left to right): Atomic radius declines as we move from left to right in a period. This occurs because, in a period, the outermost electrons are in the same valence shell, but the atomic number increases from left to right. This increase in atomic number results in an increase in the effective nuclear charge. Therefore, the attraction of electrons towards the nucleus is increased, pulling the electrons closer.

Down a group (top to bottom): Atomic radius increases as we move down a group. This happens because as we move down a group, there is an increase in the principal quantum number (n), which leads to an increase in the distance between the nucleus and the valence electrons. New shells are added, making the atom larger.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.10: Explain why there is variation in atomic radius in a group and period?... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Explain what is isoelectronic species? Give names of the species which will be isoelectronic species with each ion or atom given below.
1. Ar
2. Rb+
3. F−
4. Mg+
questions.solutionContent:
Ions and atoms which are having an equal number of electrons are called isoelectronic species.

1. Ar (Argon) has 18 electrons. Some isoelectronic species are:
S2− ion (16 + 2 = 18 electrons)
Cl− ion (17 + 1 = 18 electrons)
K+ ion (19 – 1 = 18 electrons)

2. Rb+ (Rubidium) has 36 electrons (37 – 1 = 36). Some isoelectronic species are:
Br− ion (35 + 1 = 36 electrons)
Kr ion (36 electrons)
Sr2+ ion (38 – 2 = 36 electrons)

3. F− (Fluorine) ion has 10 electrons (9 + 1 = 10). Some isoelectronic species are:
Na+ ion (11 – 1 = 10 electrons)
Ne ion (10 electrons)
Al3+ ion (13 – 3 = 10 electrons)

4. Mg+ (Magnesium) ion has 11 electrons (12 – 1 = 11). Some isoelectronic species are:
Al2+ ion (13 – 2 = 11 electrons)
Na ion (11 electrons)
Si3+ ion (14 – 3 = 11 electrons)
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.11: Explain what is isoelectronic species? Give names of the species which will be isoelectronic species with each ion or at... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Consider the accompanying species: N3−, O2−, F−, Na+, Mg2+, and Al3+
(i) What is similar in them?
(ii) Arrange them in the according to their increasing order of ionic radii.
questions.solutionContent:
(i) The given species (N3−, O2−, F−, Na+, Mg2+, and Al3+) all have an equal number of electrons, specifically 10 electrons. Therefore, they are isoelectronic species.

(ii) The arrangement of these ions according to their increasing order of nuclear charge is:
N3− < O2− < F− < Na+ < Mg2+ < Al3+

The arrangement of the given ions according to their increasing order of ionic radii is:
Al3+ < Mg2+ < Na+ < F− < O2− < N3−

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText: Cation are having smaller radii then that of their parent atom and anion are having larger radii than their parent atom. Why?
questions.solutionContent:
Cations are formed when an electron is expelled from the outermost orbit of an atom. This means a cation has fewer electrons compared to its parent atom. While the total nuclear charge remains the same, the effective nuclear charge increases because the same positive charge is now attracting fewer electrons. This results in an increased attraction of electrons towards the nucleus compared to the parent atom. Thus, cations have smaller radii than their parent atom.

Anions are formed when an electron is gained into the outermost orbit of an atom. This means an anion has more electrons compared to its parent atom. While the total nuclear charge remains the same, the increased number of electrons leads to increased electron-electron repulsion and a decreased effective nuclear charge. This results in a decreased attraction of electrons towards the nucleus, leading to an increased distance between the nucleus and the valence electrons compared to the parent atom. Thus, anions have larger radii than their parent atom.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.13: Cation are having smaller radii then that of their parent atom and anion are having larger radii than their parent atom.... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
State significance of following terms:
1. “isolated gaseous atom”
2. “ground state”
in the definition of ionization enthalpy and electron gain enthalpy?
questions.solutionContent:
Isolated gaseous atom: Ionisation enthalpy is defined as the energy required to expel an electron from an isolated gaseous atom in ground state. Even in a gaseous state, atoms are widely separated, but there are still some attractive forces between them. To accurately find the ionization enthalpy of an ion, it is difficult to isolate a single atom. These attractive forces can be further diminished by lowering the pressure. Therefore, the term isolated gaseous atom is used to ensure that the measured enthalpy change is solely due to the electron removal/addition from/to a single atom, without interference from intermolecular forces.

Ground state: An atom's ground state is its most stable state. Less energy is required to expel an electron if the isolated gaseous atom is in its ground state. Thus, for the purpose of comparison and consistency, both electron gain enthalpy and ionization enthalpy must be calculated for an isolated gaseous atom in its ground state.

1. “isolated gaseous atom”
2. “ground state”
in the definition of ioniza... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Determine ionization enthalpy of Hydrogen atom in Jmol−1.
Electron of hydrogen is having −2.18∗10−18 J in ground state.
questions.solutionContent:
It is given that the electron of hydrogen has –2.18 × 10−18 J in the ground state. Therefore, 2.18 × 10−18 J of energy will be required to expel an electron from the ground state in a H (hydrogen) atom.

Thus, for a Hydrogen atom, the Ionisation enthalpy = 2.18 × 10−18 J.

To convert this to J mol−1, we multiply by Avogadro's number (6.02 × 1023 mol−1).
Ionisation enthalpy of Hydrogen atom in J mol−1 = 2.18 × 10−18 J × 6.02 × 1023 mol−1 = 1.312 × 10⁶ J mol⁻¹

NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.15: Determine ionization enthalpy of Hydrogen atom in Jmol−1.

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
For some elements of the 2nd period the arrangement according to their ionization enthalpy is given as follows
LiExplain Why?
1. ΔiH for O is lower than ΔiH of N and F.
2. ΔiH for Be is higher than ΔiH than B?
questions.solutionContent:
1. ΔiH for O is lower than ΔiH of N and F:
- ΔiH for O is lower than ΔiH of N: In nitrogen, there are three 2p-electrons, and all three occupy distinct atomic orbitals (half-filled stability). In oxygen, 2 out of 4, 2p-electrons occupy the same 2p-orbital (Pauli repulsion), which increases the repulsion between electrons in the oxygen atom. Thus, the energy required to expel the 4th 2p-electron in oxygen atom (which causes increased repulsion) is lower than the energy required to expel a 2p-electron from the stable half-filled configuration of nitrogen.
- ΔiH for O is lower than ΔiH of F: A fluorine atom has one proton and one electron more than an oxygen atom. As the electron is added to the same shell, the increase in attractive force between the nucleus and the electron (due to the added proton) is higher than the increase in repulsive force between electron-electron (due to the added electron). Thus, valence electrons in the fluorine atom experience a higher effective nuclear charge compared to the electrons of an oxygen atom. Consequently, the energy required to expel an electron from fluorine is higher than that from oxygen. Therefore, ΔiH for O is lower than ΔiH of F.

2. ΔiH for Be is higher than ΔiH than B:
During the ionization process, the electron expelled from a Be (beryllium) atom is a 2s-electron, whereas the electron expelled from boron is a 2p-electron. The attractive force between a 2s-electron and the nucleus is stronger than between a 2p-electron and the nucleus, due to better penetration of the 2s orbital. Thus, the energy required to expel a 2s-electron is higher than the energy required to expel a 2p-electron. Therefore, ΔiH for Be is higher than ΔiH for B.
questions.altText:
NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.16: For some elements of the 2nd period the arrangement according to their ionization enthalpy is given as follows
Li

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText: Explain why the 1st ionization enthalpy of magnesium is higher than 1st ionization enthalpy of sodium but the 2nd ionization enthalpy of magnesium is lower than 2nd ionization enthalpy of sodium?
questions.solutionContent:
1st ionization enthalpy of magnesium is higher than 1st ionization enthalpy of sodium:
Magnesium has a smaller atomic size and a higher effective nuclear charge than sodium. Additionally, Mg has a stable, fully-filled 3s² configuration. Thus, more energy is required to expel an electron from magnesium than from sodium. Therefore, the 1st ionization enthalpy of magnesium is higher than the 1st ionization enthalpy of sodium.

2nd ionization enthalpy of magnesium is lower than 2nd ionization enthalpy of sodium:
After expelling one electron, magnesium still has one electron remaining in the 3s-orbital (Mg+ is [Ne]3s¹), and it needs to lose another electron to achieve a stable inert gas configuration. In contrast, after expelling one electron, sodium achieves a stable inert gas configuration (Na+ is [Ne]). Therefore, the energy required to expel a second electron from magnesium is lower than that from sodium because removing an electron from a stable noble gas configuration (like Na+) requires significantly more energy. Thus, the 2nd ionization enthalpy of magnesium is lower than the 2nd ionization enthalpy of sodium.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.17: Explain why the 1st ionization enthalpy of magnesium is higher than 1st ionization enthalpy of sodium but the 2nd ioniza... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText: State the factors because of which in elements of main group the ionization enthalpy decreases when we move down the group.
questions.solutionContent:
The factors due to which ionization enthalpy decreases as we move down the group in main group elements are:

Increase in the shielding effect: As we move down the group, the number of inner shells increases. This leads to an increase in the shielding effect of valence electrons from the nucleus by the inner core electrons. Consequently, the attractive force on valence electrons towards the nucleus weakens. So, less energy is required to expel a valence electron, and ionization enthalpy decreases as we move down the group.

Increase in atomic size of elements: As we move down the group, the number of inner shells increases, causing the atomic size to increase. This increases the distance between the valence electron and the nucleus of an atom, meaning the electrons are not as strongly bound. Therefore, valence electrons can be expelled more easily. Thus, the energy required to expel a valence electron decreases as we move down the group.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.18: State the factors because of which in elements of main group the ionization enthalpy decreases when we move down the gro... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
For the elements of group 13 the values of 1st ionization enthalpy is given below:
B Al Ga In Tl
801 577 579 558 589
Explain the ‘deviation from the general trend’?
questions.solutionContent:
Generally, ionization enthalpy decreases as we move down a group due to increased shielding effect and increased atomic size. Hence, for elements of group 13, the ionization enthalpy decreases as we move down from Boron (B) to Aluminium (Al).

However, there are deviations:

Ga is having higher ionization enthalpy than Al: This is because Al comes after s-block elements, while Ga comes after d-block elements. The shielding provided by electrons of d-block elements is not effective. Consequently, valence electrons in the Ga atom experience a higher effective nuclear charge compared to Al.

Tl is having higher ionization enthalpy than In: Further down from Ga to In, the ionization enthalpy value decreases due to the increase in shielding effect and atomic size. But Thallium (Tl) has a higher ionization enthalpy than Indium (In). This is because Tl comes after both '4f and 5d electrons'. The shielding provided by these '4f and 5d electrons' is also not effective. As a result, valence electrons in the Tl atom experience a higher effective nuclear charge compared to In.

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Find out which of the pair given below will have high negative electron affinity?
a)F or Cl
b) O or F
questions.solutionContent:
a) F or Cl: F and Cl are elements of the same group. Generally, electron affinity becomes less negative on moving down a group. However, the electron affinity of F is less negative than that of Cl. This is because the atomic size of Cl is larger than that of F. In Cl, the electron will be added to the n=3 quantum level, whereas in F, the electron will be added to the n=2 quantum level. Since electron-electron repulsion is reduced in Cl due to the larger shell, an extra electron can be more easily accommodated. Therefore, the electron affinity of Cl is more negative compared to that of F.

b) O or F: O and F are elements of the same period. An F-atom has 1 electron and 1 proton more than an O-atom, and the electron is added to the same shell. While the atomic size of O-atom is larger than F-atom, the nucleus of an O-atom has one less proton than an F-atom, meaning it cannot attract an incoming electron as strongly as an F-atom can. Also, an F-atom requires only 1 electron to achieve a stable inert gas configuration. Therefore, the electron affinity of F (Fluorine) is more negative than that of O (Oxygen).
questions.altText:
NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.20: Find out which of the pair given below will have high negative electron affinity?

b) O or F... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
What is electron affinity of O(oxygen) atoms?
1.Positive
2.More negative
3.Less negative
Justify the answer.
questions.solutionContent:
When an O-atom gains one electron to form an O− ion, energy is released. So, the 1st electron affinity for O-atom is negative.
O(g) + e− → O−(g)

However, if an electron is added to an O− ion to form an O2− ion, energy is required to overcome the strong electronic repulsions between the negatively charged O− ion and the incoming electron. Therefore, the 2nd electron affinity of O-atom is positive.
O−(g) + e− → O2−(g)

1.Positive
2.More negative
3.Less negative
Justify the answer.... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText: What is the basic difference between the terms electron gain enthalpy and electronegativity?
questions.solutionContent:
Electron gain enthalpy: This is the tendency to gain electrons for an isolated gaseous atom. It is a measure of the energy change when an electron is added to a neutral atom in its gaseous state.

Electronegativity: This is the tendency to attract the shared pairs of electrons for an atom which is in a chemical compound. It is a relative measure of the power of an atom in a molecule to attract electrons to itself.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.22: What is the basic difference between the terms electron gain enthalpy and electronegativity?... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText: How would you react to the statement that the electronegativity of N on Pauling scale is 3.0 in all the nitrogen compounds?
questions.solutionContent: The statement that the electronegativity of N on the Pauling scale is 3.0 in all nitrogen compounds is incorrect. Electronegativity of an element is a variable property and differs in different compounds. For example, the electronegativity of N is different in NH3 and NO2.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.23: How would you react to the statement that the electronegativity of N on Pauling scale is 3.0 in all the nitrogen compoun... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Describe the theory associated with the radius of an atom as it
(a) gains an electron
(b) loses an electron
questions.solutionContent:
(a) When an atom gains an electron, its size increases. When an electron is added, the number of electrons increases by one. This leads to an increase in repulsion among the electrons. However, the number of protons (nuclear charge) remains the same. As a result, the effective nuclear charge of the atom decreases, allowing the electron cloud to expand, and thus the radius of the atom increases.

(b) When an atom loses an electron, its size decreases. The number of electrons decreases by one, while the nuclear charge remains the same. Therefore, the interelectronic repulsions in the atom decrease. As a result, the effective nuclear charge increases, pulling the remaining electrons closer to the nucleus. Hence, the radius of the atom decreases.
questions.altText:
NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.24: Describe the theory associated with the radius of an atom as it
(a) gains an electron
(b) loses an electron... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText: Would you expect the first ionization enthalpies for two isotopes of the same element to be the same or different? Justify your answer.
questions.solutionContent: The ionization enthalpy of an atom depends on the number of electrons and protons (nuclear charge) of that atom. Isotopes of an element have the same number of protons and electrons but differ only in the number of neutrons. Since ionization enthalpy is unaffected by the number of neutrons, the first ionization enthalpy for two isotopes of the same element should be the same.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.25: Would you expect the first ionization enthalpies for two isotopes of the same element to be the same or different? Justi... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText: What are the major differences between metals and non-metals?
questions.solutionContent:
MetalsNon–metals
1. Can lose electrons easily.1. Cannot lose electrons easily.
2. Cannot gain electrons easily.2. Can gain electrons easily.
3. Generally form ionic compounds.3. Generally form covalent compounds.
4. Oxides are basic in nature.4. Non–metallic oxides are acidic in nature.
5. Have low ionization enthalpies.5. Have high ionization enthalpies.
6. Have less negative electron gain enthalpies.6. Have high negative electron gain enthalpies.
7. Are less electronegative. They are rather electropositive elements.7. Are electronegative.
8. Have a high reducing power.8. Have a low reducing power.

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Use the periodic table to answer the following questions.
(a) Identify an element with five electrons in the outer subshell.
(b) Identify an element that would tend to lose two electrons.
(c) Identify an element that would tend to gain two electrons.
(d) Identify the group having metal, non-metal, liquid as well as gas at the room temperature.
questions.solutionContent:
(a) The electronic configuration of an element having 5 electrons in its outermost p-subshell should be ns2np5. This is the electronic configuration of the halogen group (Group 17). Thus, the element can be F, Cl, Br, I, or At.

(b) An element having two valence electrons will easily lose two electrons to attain a stable noble gas configuration. The general electronic configuration of such an element will be ns2. This is the electronic configuration of Group 2 elements (alkaline earth metals). The elements present in Group 2 are Be, Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba.

(c) An element is likely to gain two electrons if it needs only two electrons to attain the stable noble gas configuration. Thus, the general electronic configuration of such an element should be ns2np4. This is the electronic configuration of the oxygen family (Group 16).

(d) Group 17 has metal, non–metal, liquid as well as gas at room temperature. (For example, Fluorine/Chlorine are gases, Bromine is a liquid, Iodine is a solid non-metal, and Astatine is a metalloid/metal).
questions.altText:
NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties - Q3.27: Use the periodic table to answer the following questions.
(a) Identify an element with five electrons in the outer su... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText: The increasing order of reactivity among group 1 elements is Li < Na < K < Rb <Cs whereas that among group 17 elements is F > CI > Br > I. Explain.
questions.solutionContent:
Group 1 elements (Li < Na < K < Rb < Cs): Elements in Group 1 have only 1 valence electron, which they tend to lose to achieve stability. As we move down Group 1, the ionization enthalpies decrease. This means the energy required to lose the valence electron decreases, making it easier for the atom to lose an electron. Thus, reactivity increases on moving down Group 1.

Group 17 elements (F > Cl > Br > I): Group 17 elements need only one electron to attain the noble gas configuration. As we move down Group 17 from Cl to I, the electron gain enthalpy becomes less negative, meaning their tendency to gain electrons decreases. Thus, reactivity decreases down Group 17.
However, fluorine (F) is an exception: despite its electron gain enthalpy being less negative than Cl, it is the most reactive halogen. This is primarily because of its low bond dissociation energy, making it easier for F2 to break apart and react.

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Assign the position of the element having outer electronic configuration
(i) ns2np4 for n = 3
(ii) (n - 1)d2ns2 for n = 4, and
(iii) (n - 2)f7(n - 1)d1ns2 for n = 6, in the periodic table.
questions.solutionContent:
(i) ns2np4 for n = 3:
Since n = 3, the element belongs to the 3rd period.
It is a p–block element because the last electron occupies the p–orbital.
There are four electrons in the p–orbital (np4).
The corresponding group of the element = 2 (s-block) + 10 (d-block) + 4 (p-electrons) = 16.
Therefore, the element is in the 3rd period and 16th group. Hence, the element is Sulphur (S).

(ii) (n - 1)d2ns2 for n = 4:
Since n = 4, the element belongs to the 4th period.
It is a d–block element as d–orbitals are incompletely filled ((n-1)d2).
There are 2 electrons in the d–orbital.
The corresponding group of the element = 2 (s-block) + 2 (d-block electrons) = 4.
Therefore, it is a 4th period and 4th group element. Hence, the element is Titanium (Ti).

(iii) (n - 2)f7(n - 1)d1ns2 for n = 6:
Since n = 6, the element is present in the 6th period.
It is an f–block element as the last electron occupies the f–orbital ((n-2)f7).
It belongs to Group 3 of the periodic table, as all f-block elements belong to Group 3.
Its electronic configuration is [Xe] 4f7 5d1 6s2. Thus, its atomic number is 54 (for Xe) + 7 + 1 + 2 = 64.
Hence, the element is Gadolinium (Gd).

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
The first (ΔiH1) and the second (ΔiH2) ionization enthalpies (in kJ mol–1) and the (ΔegH) electron gain enthalpy (in kJ mol–1) of a few elements are given below:
Elements ΔiH1 ΔiH2 ΔegH
I 520 7300 –60
II 419 3051 –48
III 1681 3374 –328
IV 1008 1846 –295
V 2372 5251 +48
VI 738 1451 –40
Which of the above elements is likely to be :
(a) the least reactive element.
(b) the most reactive metal.
(c) the most reactive non-metal.
(d) the least reactive non-metal.
(e) the metal which can form a stable binary halide of the formula MX2, (X=halogen).
(f) the metal which can form a predominantly stable covalent halide of the formula MX (X=halogen)?
questions.solutionContent:
(a) Element V is likely to be the least reactive element. This is because it has the highest first ionization enthalpy (ΔiH1) (2372 kJ mol−1) and a positive electron gain enthalpy (ΔegH) (+48 kJ mol−1). These characteristics are typical of noble gases.

(b) Element II is likely to be the most reactive metal. It has the lowest first ionization enthalpy (ΔiH1) (419 kJ mol−1) and a low negative electron gain enthalpy (ΔegH) (-48 kJ mol−1).

(c) Element III is likely to be the most reactive non–metal. It has a high first ionization enthalpy (ΔiH1) (1681 kJ mol−1) and the highest negative electron gain enthalpy (ΔegH) (-328 kJ mol−1).

(d) Element V is likely to be the least reactive non–metal. Its properties are characteristic of noble gases.

(e) Element VI has a low negative electron gain enthalpy (ΔegH) (-40 kJ mol−1), indicating it is a metal. Its relatively low second ionization enthalpy (ΔiH2) (1451 kJ mol−1) suggests it readily forms a +2 ion. Hence, it can form a stable binary halide of the formula MX2.

(f) The question has a slight ambiguity. Assuming it refers to an element forming a covalent bond, Element I has a very high second ionization enthalpy, making the formation of a +2 ion very difficult, but a low first IE. This suggests it would readily form a +1 ion and a halide MX. If covalent character is emphasized, one might look at non-metals, but they don't form halides of formula MX with X=halogen typically. Based on ionic/covalent tendencies, Element I is the best fit for forming MX compounds.

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Predict the formula of the stable binary compounds that would be formed by the combination of the following pairs of elements.
(a) Lithium and oxygen
(b) Magnesium and nitrogen
(c) Aluminium and iodine
(d) Silicon and oxygen
(e) Phosphorus and fluorine
(f) Element 71 and fluorine
questions.solutionContent:
(a) Lithium (Li) is in Group 1, valency 1. Oxygen (O) is in Group 16, valency 2. Formula: Li2O.
(b) Magnesium (Mg) is in Group 2, valency 2. Nitrogen (N) is in Group 15, valency 3. Formula: Mg3N2.
(c) Aluminium (Al) is in Group 13, valency 3. Iodine (I) is in Group 17, valency 1. Formula: AlI3.
(d) Silicon (Si) is in Group 14, valency 4. Oxygen (O) is in Group 16, valency 2. Formula: SiO2.
(e) Phosphorus (P) is in Group 15. Fluorine (F) is in Group 17, valency 1. Phosphorus can exhibit valencies of 3 or 5. Formula: PF3 or PF5.
(f) The element with atomic number 71 is Lutetium (Lu). Lutetium has a common valency of 3. Fluorine (F) has a valency of 1. Hence, the formula of the compound is LuF3.

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
In the modern periodic table, the period indicates the value of:
(a) Atomic number
(b) Atomic mass
(c) Principal quantum number
(d) Azimuthal quantum number.
questions.solutionContent: The correct answer is (c) Principal quantum number. The value of the principal quantum number (n) for the outermost shell or the valence shell indicates a period in the Modern periodic table.

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Which of the following statements related to the modern periodic table is incorrect?
(a) The p-block has 6 columns, because a maximum of 6 electrons can occupy all the orbitals in a p-shell.
(b) The d-block has 8 columns, because a maximum of 8 electrons can occupy all the orbitals in a d-subshell.
(c) Each block contains a number of columns equal to the number of electrons that can occupy that subshell.
(d) The block indicates value of azimuthal quantum number (l) for the last subshell that received electrons in building up the electronic configuration.
questions.solutionContent: The incorrect statement is (b). The d-block has 10 columns, not 8, because a maximum of 10 electrons can occupy all the orbitals in a d-subshell (5 orbitals * 2 electrons/orbital = 10 electrons).

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Anything that influences the valence electrons will affect the chemistry of the element. Which one of the following factors does not affect the valence shell?
(a) Valence principal quantum number (n)
(b) Nuclear charge (Z)
(c) Nuclear mass
(d) Number of core electrons.
questions.solutionContent: The correct answer is (c) Nuclear mass. Nuclear mass does not affect the valence electrons. The valence principal quantum number (n), nuclear charge (Z), and number of core electrons (which contribute to shielding) all directly influence the valence electrons.

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
The size of isoelectronic species — F–, Ne and Na+ is affected by
(a) Nuclear charge (Z)
(b) Valence principal quantum number (n)
(c) Electron-electron interaction in the outer orbitals
(d) None of the factors because their size is the same.
questions.solutionContent: The correct answer is (a) Nuclear charge (Z). The size of an isoelectronic species is primarily affected by its nuclear charge (Z). The size increases with a decrease in the nuclear charge. For F−, Ne, and Na+, the order of increasing nuclear charge is F− < Ne < Na+, so the order of increasing size is Na+ < Ne < F−.

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Which one of the following statements is incorrect in relation to ionization enthalpy?
(a) Ionization enthalpy increases for each successive electron.
(b) The greatest increase in ionization enthalpy is experienced on removal of electron from core noble gas configuration.
(c) End of valence electrons is marked by a big jump in ionization enthalpy.
(d) Removal of electron from orbitals bearing lower n value is easier than from orbital having higher n value.
questions.solutionContent: The incorrect statement is (d). Electrons in orbitals bearing a lower n value are more attracted to the nucleus than electrons in orbitals bearing a higher n value because they are closer to the nucleus. Hence, the removal of electrons from orbitals bearing a higher n value is easier than the removal of electrons from orbitals having a lower n value.

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Considering the elements B, Al, Mg, and K, the correct order of their metallic character is:
(a) B > Al > Mg > K
(b) Al > Mg > B > K
(c) Mg > Al > K > B
(d) K > Mg > Al > B
questions.solutionContent:
The correct answer is (d) K > Mg > Al > B.
The metallic character of elements decreases from left to right across a period (Mg > Al).
The metallic character of elements increases down a group (Al > B; K > Na).
Considering these trends, the overall order of metallic character is K > Mg > Al > B.

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Considering the elements B, C, N, F, and Si, the correct order of their non-metallic character is:
(a) B > C > Si > N > F
b) Si > C > B > N > F
(c) F > N > C > B > Si
d) F > N > C > Si > B
questions.solutionContent:
The correct answer is (c) F > N > C > B > Si.
The non-metallic character of elements increases from left to right across a period (F > N > C > B).
The non-metallic character of elements decreases down a group (C > Si).
Combining these trends, the correct order of non-metallic character is F > N > C > B > Si.

questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.questionText:
Considering the elements F, Cl, O and N, the correct order of their chemical reactivity in terms of oxidizing property is:
(a) F > Cl > O > N
(b) F > O > Cl > N
(c) Cl > F > O > N
(d) O > F > N > Cl
questions.solutionContent:
The correct answer is (b) F > O > Cl > N.
The oxidizing character (electronegativity) increases from left to right across a period (F > O > N).
The oxidizing character decreases down a group (F > Cl).
Oxygen is more electronegative than Chlorine.
Hence, the correct order is F > O > Cl > N.

questions.questionText: Calculate the molecular mass of the following:(i) H₂O (ii) CO₂ (iii) CH₄
questions.solutionContent:
(i) H₂O:
Molecular weight of water, H₂O = (2 × Atomic weight of hydrogen) + (1 × Atomic weight of oxygen)
= [2(1.008 u) + 1(16.00 u)]
= 2.016 u + 16.00 u = 18.016 u

(ii) CO2:
Molecular weight of carbon dioxide, CO₂ = (1 × Atomic weight of carbon) + (2 × Atomic weight of oxygen)
= [1(12.011 u) + 2(16.00 u)]
= 12.011 u + 32.00 u = 44.011 u

(iii) CH₄ (Methane):
Molecular weight of methane, CH₄ = (1 × Atomic weight of carbon) + (4 × Atomic weight of hydrogen)
= [1(12.011 u) + 4(1.008 u)]
= 12.011 u + 4.032 u = 16.043 u

questions.questionText: Calculate the mass percent of different elements present in Sodium Sulphate (Na₂SO₄).
questions.solutionContent:
Molar mass of Na₂SO₄ = [(2 x 23.0) + (32.00) + 4(16.00)] = 142 g
Mass percent of an element = (Mass of that element in compound / Molar mass of that compound) × 100
Mass percent of sodium (Na): (46/142) × 100 = 32.39%
Mass percent of sulphur (S): (32/142) × 100 = 22.54%
Mass percent of oxygen (O): (64/142) × 100 = 45.07%

questions.questionText: Determine the empirical formula of an oxide of iron which has 69.9% iron and 30.1% dioxygen by mass.
questions.solutionContent:
% of iron by mass = 69.9 % [Given]
% of oxygen by mass = 30.1 % [Given]
Atomic mass of iron = 55.85 amu
Atomic mass of oxygen = 16.00 amu
Relative moles of iron = 69.9/55.85 = 1.25
Relative moles of oxygen = 30.01/16 = 1.88
Simplest molar ratio = 1.25/1.25 : 1.88/1.25
⇒ 1 : 1.5 = 2 : 3∴
The empirical formula of the iron oxide is Fe₂O₃. |

questions.questionText: Calculate the amount of carbon dioxide that could be produced when: (i) 1 mole of carbon is burnt in air. (ii) 1 mole of carbon is burnt in 16 g of dioxygen. (iii) 2 moles of carbon are burnt in 16 g of dioxygen.
questions.solutionContent:
The balanced reaction is: C(s) + O₂(g) → CO₂(g)
(i) 1 mole of carbon is burnt in air:
Since the combustion is complete, 1 mole of carbon dioxide is produced.

(ii) 1 mole of carbon is burnt in 16 g of dioxygen:
Oxygen acts as a limiting reagent (16 g = 0.5 mole). It will react with 0.5 mole of carbon to give 22 g of carbon dioxide.

(iii) 2 moles of carbon are burnt in 16 g of dioxygen:
Oxygen again acts as a limiting reagent (0.5 mole). It can combine with only 0.5 mole of carbon to give 22 g of carbon dioxide.

questions.questionText: Calculate the mass of sodium acetate (CH₃COONa) required to make 500 mL of 0.375 molar aqueous solution. Molar mass of sodium acetate is 82.0245 g mol⁻¹.
questions.solutionContent:
0.375 M aqueous solution means 1000 mL solution contains 0.375 moles of sodium acetate.
∴ No. of moles of sodium acetate in 500 mL = (0.375/1000) × 500 = 0.375/2 = 0.1875 moles
Molar mass of sodium acetate = 82.0245 g mol⁻¹
∴ Mass of sodium acetate required = 0.1875 × 82.0245 g = 15.380 g |

questions.questionText: Calculate the concentration of nitric acid in moles per litre in a sample which has a density, 1.41 g mL⁻¹ and the mass per cent of nitric acid in it being 69%.
questions.solutionContent:
Mass percent of 69% means 100g of nitric acid solution contains 69 g of nitric acid by mass.
Molar mass of nitric acid (HNO₃) = 1+14+48 = 63 g mol⁻¹
Number of moles in 69 g of HNO₃ = 69/63 moles = 1.095 moles
Volume of 100g nitric acid solution = 100/1.41 mL = 70.92 mL = 0.07092 L
∴ Concentration of HNO₃ in moles per litre = 1.095/0.07092 = 15.44 M |

questions.questionText: How much copper can be obtained from 100 g of copper sulphate (CuSO₄)?
questions.solutionContent:
1 mole of CuSO₄ contains 1 mole of copper.
Molar mass of CuSO₄ = (63.5) + (32.00) + 4(16.00)
= 63.5 + 32.00 + 64.00 = 159.5 g
159.5 g of CuSO₄ contains 63.5 g of copper.
∴ Copper obtained from 100 g of copper sulphate = (63.5/159.5) × 100 = 39.81 g

questions.questionText: Determine the molecular formula of an oxide of iron in which the mass per cent of iron and oxygen are 69.9 and 30.1 respectively. Given that the molar mass of the oxide is 159.69 g mol⁻¹.
questions.solutionContent:
% of iron by mass = 69.9 % [Given]
% of oxygen by mass = 30.1 % [Given]
Atomic mass of iron = 55.85 amu
Atomic mass of oxygen = 16.00 amu
Relative moles of iron = 69.9/55.85 = 1.25
Relative moles of oxygen = 30.01/16 = 1.88
Simplest molar ratio = 1.25/1.25 : 1.88/1.25
⇒ 1 : 1.5 = 2 : 3
∴ The empirical formula of the iron oxide is Fe₂O₃.
Mass of Fe₂O₃ = (2×55.85) + (3×16.00) = 159.7 g mol⁻¹
n = Molar mass / Empirical formula mass = 159.7 / 159.6 = 1 (approx)
Thus, Molecular formula is same as Empirical Formula i.e., Fe₂O₃.

= 26.4959 + 8.9568 = 35.4527

questions.questionText: In three moles of ethane (C₂H₆), calculate the following: (i) Number of moles of carbon atoms. (ii) Number of moles of hydrogen atoms. (iii) Number of molecules of ethane.
questions.solutionContent:
(i) 1 mole of C₂H₆ contains 2 moles of Carbon atoms
∴ 3 moles of C₂H₆ will contain 6 moles of Carbon atoms.
(ii) 1 mole of C₂H₆ contains 6 moles of Hydrogen atoms
∴ 3 moles of C₂H₆ will contain 18 moles of Hydrogen atoms.
(iii) 1 mole of C₂H₆ contains Avogadro's no. (6.02 × 10²³ molecules)
∴ 3 moles of C₂H₆ will contain ethane molecules = 3 × 6.02 × 10²³ = 18.06 × 10²³ molecules.

questions.questionText: What is the concentration of sugar (C₁₂H₂₂O₁₁) in mol L⁻¹ if its 20 g are dissolved in enough water to make a final volume up to 2L?
questions.solutionContent:
Molar mass of sugar (C₁₂H₂₂O₁₁) = (12 × 12) + (1 × 22) + (11 × 16) = 342 g mol⁻¹
No. of moles in 20g of sugar = 20/342 = 0.0585 mole
Volume of Solution = 2 L (given)
Molar concentration = Moles of solute / Volume of solution in L = 0.0585 mol / 2 L = 0.0293 mol L⁻¹ = 0.0293 M

questions.questionText: If the density of methanol is 0.793 kg L⁻¹, what is its volume needed for making 2.5 L of its 0.25 M solution?
questions.solutionContent:
Molar mass of methanol (CH₃OH) = (1×12) + (4×1) + (1×16) = 32 g mol⁻¹ = 0.032 kg mol⁻¹
Molarity of the solution = 0.793 / 0.032 = 24.78 mol L⁻¹
Applying, M₁V₁ (Given Solution) = M₂V₂ (Solution to be prepared)
24.78 × V₁ = 0.25 × 2.5 L
V₁ = 0.02522 L = 25.22 mL

questions.questionText: Pressure is determined as force per unit area of the surface. The SI unit of pressure, pascal is as shown below: 1Pa = 1N m⁻² If mass of air at sea level is 1034 g cm⁻², calculate the pressure in pascal.
questions.solutionContent:
Pressure is the force (i.e. weight) acting per unit area.
P = F/A = 1034g × 9.8ms⁻² / cm²
= 1034g × 9.8ms⁻² / cm² × 1kg / 1000g × 100cm / 1m × 100cm / 1m = 1.01332 × 10⁵ N
Now, 1Pa = 1N m⁻²
∴ 1.01332 × 10⁵ N × m⁻² = 1.01332 × 10⁵ Pa

questions.questionText: What is the SI unit of mass? How is it defined?
questions.solutionContent:
The SI unit of mass is kilogram (kg).
The kg is defined as the mass of platinum-iridium (Pt-Ir) cylinder that is stored in an air-tight jar at the International Bureau of Weight and Measures in France.

questions.questionText: What do you mean by significant figures?
questions.solutionContent:
Significant figures are meaningful digits which are known with certainty including the last digit whose value is uncertain.
For example, in 11.2546 g, there are 6 significant figures. Here, 11.254 is certain and 6 is uncertain, with the uncertainty being ±1 in the last digit.
The last uncertain digit is also included in significant figures.

questions.questionText:
A sample of drinking water was found to be severely contaminated with chloroform, CHCl₃, supposed to be carcinogenic in nature. The level of contamination was 15 ppm (by mass).
(i) Express this in percent by mass.
(ii) Determine the molality of chloroform in the water sample.
questions.solutionContent:
(i) 15 ppm means 15 parts in million (10⁶) parts.
∴ % by mass = (15/10⁶) × 100 = 15 × 10⁻⁴ = 1.5 × 10⁻³ %
(ii) Molar mass of chloroform (CHCl₃) = 12 + 1 + (3 × 35.5) = 118.5 g mol⁻¹.
100g of the sample contain chloroform = 1.5 × 10⁻³ g.
∴ 1000 g (1 kg) of the sample will contain chloroform = 1.5 × 10⁻² g
= 1.5 × 10⁻² / 118.65 mole = 1.266 × 10⁻⁴ mole.
∴ Molality = 1.266 × 10⁻⁴ m.

questions.questionText:
The following data are obtained when dinitrogen and dioxygen react together to form different compounds: Mass of dinitrogen Mass of dioxygen (i)14 g 16 g (ii)14 g 32 g (iii)28 g 32 g (iv)28 g 80 g
(a) Which law of chemical combination is obeyed by the above experimental data? Give its statement.
(b) Fill in the blanks in the following conversions:
(i) 1 km = ...................... mm = ...................... pm
(ii) 1 mg = ...................... kg = ...................... ng
(iii) 1 mL = ...................... L = ...................... dm³
questions.solutionContent:
(a) Fixing the mass of dinitrogen as 28 g, masses of dioxygen combined will be 32, 64, 32 and 80 g in the given four oxides. These masses of dioxygen bear a simple whole number ratio as 2:4:2:5. Hence, the data given will obey the law of multiple proportions.
Statement of Law of Multiple Proportions: If two elements combine to form more than one compound, the masses of one element that combine with a fixed mass of the other element are in ratios of small whole numbers.
(b) Conversions:
(i) 1 km = 1 km × (1000m/1km) × (100cm/1m) × (10mm/1cm) = 10⁶ mm
1 km = 1 km × (1000m/1km) × (1pm/10⁻¹²m) = 10¹⁵ pm

(ii) 1 mg = 1 mg × (1g/1000mg) × (1kg/1000g) = 10⁻⁶ kg
1 mg = 1 mg × (1g/1000mg) × (1ng/10⁻⁹g) = 10⁶ ng
(iii) 1 mL = 1 mL × (1L/1000mL) = 10⁻³ L
1 mL = 1 cm³ = 1 cm³ × (1dm/10cm)³ = 10⁻³ dm³

questions.questionText: If the speed of light is 3.0 × 10⁸ ms⁻¹, calculate the distance covered by light in 2.00 ns.
questions.solutionContent:
Distance covered = Speed × Time
= 3.0 × 10⁸ ms⁻¹ × 2.00 ns
= 3.0 × 10⁸ ms⁻¹ × 2.00 ns × (10⁻⁹ s / 1 ns)
= 6.00 × 10⁻¹ m = 0.600 m

questions.questionText:
In a reaction A + B₂ → AB₂ Identify the limiting reagent, if any, in the following reaction mixtures.
(i) 300 atoms of A + 200 molecules of B
(ii) 2 mol A + 3 mol B
(iii) 100 atoms of A + 100 molecules of B
(iv) 5 mol A + 2.5 mol B
(v) 2.5 mol A + 5 mol B
questions.solutionContent:
According to the reaction, 1 atom of A reacts with 1 molecule of B.
(i) 200 molecules of B will react with 200 atoms of A, leaving 100 atoms of A unreacted. Hence, B is the limiting reagent.
(ii) 2 mol of A will react with only 2 mol of B, leaving 1 mol of B. Hence, A is the limiting reagent.
(iii) All 100 atoms of A will combine with all 100 molecules of B. Hence, the mixture is stoichiometric and there is no limiting reagent.
(iv) 2.5 mol of B will combine with only 2.5 mol of A, and 2.5 mol of A will be left unreacted. Hence, B is the limiting reagent.
(v) 2.5 mol of A will combine with only 2.5 mol of B, and the remaining 2.5 mol of B will be left. Hence, A is the limiting reagent.

questions.questionText:
Dinitrogen and dihydrogen react with each other to produce ammonia according to the following chemical equation: N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) → 2NH₃(g)
(i) Calculate the mass of ammonia produced if 2.00×10³ g dinitrogen reacts with 1.00×10³ g of dihydrogen.
(ii) Will any of the two reactants remain unreacted?
(iii) If yes, which one and what would be its mass?
questions.solutionContent:
From the equation: 1 mole of dinitrogen (28g) reacts with 3 moles of dihydrogen (6g) to give 2 moles of ammonia (34g).
(i) 2000 g of N₂ will react with H₂ = (6/28) × 2000g = 428.6 g.
Thus, N₂ is the limiting reagent while H₂ is in excess.
28g of N₂ produces 34g of NH₃.
∴ 2000g of N₂ will produce = (34/28) × 2000g = 2428.57 g of NH₃.
(ii) Yes, H₂ (dihydrogen) will remain unreacted as N₂ is the limiting reagent and H₂ is the excess reagent.
(iii) Mass of dihydrogen left unreacted = 1000g - 428.6g = 571.4 g.

questions.questionText: How are 0.50 mol Na₂CO₃ and 0.50 M Na₂CO₃ different?
questions.solutionContent:
Molar mass of Na₂CO₃ = (2×23) + 12.00 + (3×16) = 106 g mol⁻¹.
0.50 mol Na₂CO₃ means 0.50 × 106g = 53g of Na₂CO₃.
0.50 M Na₂CO₃ means 0.50 mol of Na₂CO₃ (i.e., 53g of Na₂CO₃) are present in 1 litre of the solution.

questions.questionText: If ten volumes of dihydrogen gas reacts with five volumes of dioxygen gas, how many volumes of water vapour would be produced?
questions.solutionContent:
Dihydrogen gas reacts with dioxygen gas as: 2H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2H₂O(g).
Thus, two volumes of dihydrogen react with one volume of dioxygen to produce two volumes of water vapour.
Hence, ten volumes of dihydrogen will react with five volumes of dioxygen to produce ten volumes of water vapour.

questions.questionText:
Which one of the following will have the largest number of atoms?
(i) 1 g Au (s)
(ii) 1 g Na (s)
(iii) 1 g Li (s)
(iv) 1 g of Cl₂(g)
questions.solutionContent:
(i) 1 g Au = (1/197) mol = (1/197) × 6.022 × 10²³ atoms
(ii) 1 g Na = (1/23) mol = (1/23) × 6.022 × 10²³ atoms
(iii) 1 g Li = (1/7) mol = (1/7) × 6.022 × 10²³ atoms
(iv) 1 g Cl₂ = (1/71) mol = (1/71) × 6.022 × 10²³ atoms
Thus, 1 g of Li has the largest number of atoms because its molar mass is the smallest, resulting in the most moles for the same mass.

questions.questionText: Calculate the molarity of a solution of ethanol in water in which the mole fraction of ethanol is 0.040 (assume the density of water to be one).
questions.solutionContent:
Mole fraction of C₂H₅OH = No. of moles of C₂H₅OH / No. of moles of solution
n(C₂H₅OH) / [n(C₂H₅OH) + n(H₂O)] = 0.040 (Given)
For a dilute solution, water is approximately 1 L.
No. of moles in 1L of water = 1000g / 18g mol⁻¹ = 55.55 moles.
Substituting n(H₂O) = 55.55:
n(C₂H₅OH) / [n(C₂H₅OH) + 55.55] = 0.040
⇒ 0.96 n(C₂H₅OH) = 55.55 × 0.040
⇒ n(C₂H₅OH) = 2.31 mol
Hence, molarity of the solution = 2.31 M.

questions.solutionContent:
(i) The least precise term, 0.112, has 3 significant figures. Therefore, the answer will have 3 significant figures.
(ii) The number 5.364 has 4 significant figures. The integer 5 is an exact number. Therefore, the answer will have 4 significant figures.
(iii) In addition/subtraction, the result should have the same number of decimal places as the term with the fewest decimal places. All terms here have 4 decimal places. Thus, the answer will have 4 decimal places, which implies a certain number of significant figures depending on the result. The source states There will be 4 significant figures in the calculation.

questions.questionText:
Calculate the number of atoms in each of the following:
(i) 52 moles of Ar
(ii) 52 u of He
(iii) 52 g of He.
questions.solutionContent:
(i) 1 mol of Ar = 6.022 × 10²³ atoms
∴ 52 mol of Ar = 52 × 6.022 × 10²³ atoms = 3.131 × 10²⁵ atoms
(ii) 1 atom of He = 4 u of He
4 u of He = 1 Atom of He
∴ 52 u of He = (1/4) × 52 = 13 atoms
(iii) 1 mol of He = 4 g = 6.022 × 10²³ atoms
∴ 52 g of He = (6.022 × 10²³ / 4) × 52 atoms = 7.8286 × 10²⁴ atoms

questions.questionText: A welding fuel gas contains carbon and hydrogen only. Burning a small sample of it in oxygen gives 3.38 g carbon dioxide, 0.690 g of water and no other products. A volume of 10.0 L (measured at STP) of this welding gas is found to weigh 11.6 g. Calculate (i) empirical formula, (ii) molar mass of the gas, and (iii) molecular formula.
questions.solutionContent:
Amount of carbon in 3.38 g of CO₂ = (12/44) × 3.38 g = 0.9218 g
Amount of hydrogen in 0.690 g H₂O = (2/18) × 0.690 g = 0.0767 g
Total mass of the compound = 0.9218 + 0.0767 = 0.9985 g
% of C in the compound = (0.9218 / 0.9985) × 100 = 92.32%
% of H in the compound = (0.0767 / 0.9985) × 100 = 7.68%
(i) Calculation of empirical formula:
Moles of carbon = 92.32/12 = 7.69
Moles of hydrogen = 7.68/1 = 7.68
Simplest molar ratio = 7.69 : 7.68 ≈ 1 : 1
∴ Empirical formula = CH
(ii) Molar mass of the gas:
10.0 L of the gas at STP weigh = 11.6 g
∴ 22.4 L of the gas at STP = (11.6/10.0) × 22.4 = 25.984 ≈ 26 g mol⁻¹
(iii) Molecular formula:
Mass of empirical formula (CH) = 12 + 1 = 13
n = Molecular Mass / Empirical Formula Mass = 26 / 13 = 2
∴ Molecular Formula = C₂H₂

questions.questionText: Calcium carbonate reacts with aqueous HCl to give CaCl₂ and CO₂ according to the reaction, CaCO₃(s) + 2HCl(aq) → CaCl₂(aq) + CO₂(g) + H₂O(l) What mass of CaCO₃ is required to react completely with 25 mL of 0.75 M HCl?
questions.solutionContent:
1000 mL of 0.75 M HCl have 0.75 mol of HCl = 0.75 × 36.5 g = 24.375 g
∴ Mass of HCl in 25mL of 0.75 M HCl = (24.375 / 1000) × 25 g = 0.6844 g
From the chemical equation:
2 mol of HCl (73 g HCl) react completely with 1 mol of CaCO₃ (100g).
∴ 0.6844 g HCl reacts completely with CaCO₃ = (100/73) × 0.6844 g = 0.938 g.

questions.questionText: Chlorine is prepared in the laboratory by treating manganese dioxide (MnO₂) with aqueous hydrochloric acid according to the reaction 4HCl(aq) + MnO₂(s) → 2H₂O(l) + MnCl₂(aq) + Cl₂(g) How many grams of HCl react with 5.0 g of manganese dioxide?
questions.solutionContent:
1 mol of MnO₂ = 55 + 32 g = 87 g.
87 g of MnO₂ react with 4 moles of HCl, which is 4 × 36.5 g = 146 g of HCl.
∴ 5.0 g of MnO₂ will react with HCl = (146/87) × 5.0 g = 8.40 g.

questions.questionText: (i) Calculate the number of electrons which will together weigh one gram. (ii) Calculate the mass and charge of one mole of electrons.
questions.solutionContent:
(i) The mass of one electron is 9.10939 × 10⁻³¹ kg.
To calculate the number of electrons that weigh 1 gram (which is 1 × 10⁻³ kg), the calculation is:
(1 × 10⁻³ kg) / (9.10939 × 10⁻³¹ kg) = 0.1098 × 10⁻³ + 31 = 0.1098 × 10²⁸ = 1.098 × 10²⁷ electrons.
(ii) Mass of one electron = 9.10939 × 10⁻³¹ kg.
Mass of one mole of electron = (6.022 × 10²³) × (9.10939 × 10⁻³¹ kg) = 5.48 × 10⁻⁷ kg.
Charge on one electron = 1.6022 × 10⁻¹⁹ coulomb.
Charge on one mole of electron = (1.6022 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) × (6.022 × 10²³) = 9.65 × 10⁴ C.

questions.questionText: (i) Calculate the total number of electrons present in one mole of methane. (ii) Find (a) the total number and (b) the total mass of neutrons in 7 mg of ¹⁴C. (Assume that mass of a neutron = 1.675 × 10⁻²⁷ kg). (iii) Find (a) the total number and (b) the total mass of protons in 34 mg of NH₃ at STP. Will the solution change if the temperature and pressure are changed?
questions.solutionContent:
(i) Number of electrons present in 1 molecule of methane (CH₄) = {1(6) + 4(1)} = 10.
Number of electrons present in 1 mole, i.e., 6.023 × 10²³ molecules of methane = 6.022 × 10²³ × 10 = 6.022 × 10²⁴.
(ii) (a) Number of atoms of ¹⁴C in 1 mole = 6.023 × 10²³.
Since 1 atom of ¹⁴C contains (14 – 6) i.e., 8 neutrons, the number of neutrons in 14 g of ¹⁴C is (6.023 × 10²³) × 8.
Number of neutrons in 7 mg = 2.4092 × 10²¹.
(b) Mass of one neutron = 1.67493 × 10⁻²⁷ kg.
Mass of total neutrons in 7 g of ¹⁴C = (2.4092 × 10²¹) × (1.67493 × 10⁻²⁷ kg) = 4.0352 × 10⁻⁶ kg.
(iii) (a) 1 mole of NH₃ = {1(14) + 3(1)} g of NH₃ = 17 g of NH₃ = 6.022 × 10²³ molecules of NH₃.
Total number of protons present in 1 molecule of NH₃ = {1(7) + 3(1)} = 10.
Number of protons in 6.023 × 10²³ molecules of NH₃ = (6.023 × 10²³) × (10) = 6.023 × 10²⁴.
So, 17 g of NH₃ contains (6.023 × 10²⁴) protons.
Number of protons in 34 mg of NH₃ = 1.2046 × 10²².
(b) Mass of one proton = 1.67493 × 10⁻²⁷ kg.
Total mass of protons in 34 mg of NH₃ = (1.67493 × 10⁻²⁷ kg) × (1.2046 × 10²²) = 2.0176 × 10⁻⁵ kg.
The number of protons, electrons, and neutrons in an atom is independent of temperature and pressure conditions. Hence, the obtained values will remain unchanged if the temperature and pressure are changed.

questions.questionText: How many neutrons and protons are there in the following nuclei? ¹³₆C, ¹⁶₈O, ²⁴₁₂Mg, ⁵⁶₂₆Fe, ⁸⁸₃₈Sr.
questions.solutionContent:
¹³₆C: Atomic mass = 13, Atomic number = Number of protons = 6, Number of neutrons = 13 – 6 = 7.
¹⁶₈O: Atomic mass = 16, Atomic number = 8, Number of protons = 8, Number of neutrons = 16 – 8 = 8.
²⁴₁₂Mg: Atomic mass = 24, Atomic number = Number of protons = 12, Number of neutrons = 24 – 12 = 12.
⁵⁶₂₆Fe: Atomic mass = 56, Atomic number = Number of protons = 26, Number of neutrons = 56 – 26 = 30.
⁸⁸₃₈Sr: Atomic mass = 88, Atomic number = Number of protons = 38, Number of neutrons = 88 – 38 = 50.

questions.questionText: Yellow light emitted from a sodium lamp has a wavelength (λ) of 580 nm. Calculate the frequency (ν) and wave number (ṽ) of the yellow light.
questions.solutionContent:
From the expression, c = νλ, we get ν = c/λ.
Where, ν = frequency of yellow light, c = velocity of light in vacuum = 3 × 10⁸ m/s, λ = wavelength of yellow light = 580 nm = 580 × 10⁻⁹ m.
Substituting the values: ν = (3 × 10⁸ m/s) / (580 × 10⁻⁹ m) = 5.17 × 10¹⁴ s⁻¹.
Wave number of yellow light, ṽ = 1/λ = 1 / (580 × 10⁻⁹ m) = 1.72 × 10⁶ m⁻¹.

questions.questionText: Find energy of each of the photons which (i) correspond to light of frequency 3 × 10¹⁵ Hz. (ii) have wavelength of 0.50 Å.
questions.solutionContent:
(i) Energy (E) of a photon is given by the expression, E = hν.
Where, h = Planck’s constant = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js, ν = frequency of light = 3 × 10¹⁵ Hz.
Substituting the values: E = (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js) × (3 × 10¹⁵ Hz) = 1.988 × 10⁻¹⁸ J.
(ii) Energy (E) of a photon having wavelength (λ) is given by the expression, E = hc/λ.
h = Planck’s constant = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js, c = velocity of light in vacuum = 3 × 10⁸ m/s, λ = 0.50 Å = 0.50 × 10⁻¹⁰ m.
Substituting the values: E = (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js × 3 × 10⁸ m/s) / (0.50 × 10⁻¹⁰ m) = 3.9756 × 10⁻¹⁵ J.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.6: Find energy of each of the photons which (i) correspond to light of frequency 3 × 10¹⁵ Hz. (ii) have wavelength of 0.50 ... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: Calculate the wavelength, frequency and wave number of a light wave whose period is 2.0 × 10⁻¹⁰ s.
questions.solutionContent:
Frequency (ν) of light = 1/Period = 1 / (2.0 × 10⁻¹⁰ s) = 5.0 × 10⁹ s⁻¹.
Wavelength (λ) of light = c/ν, where c = velocity of light in vacuum = 3 × 10⁸ m/s.
Substituting the value: λ = (3 × 10⁸ m/s) / (5.0 × 10⁹ s⁻¹) = 6.0 × 10⁻² m.
Wave number (ṽ) of light = 1/λ = 1 / (6.0 × 10⁻² m) = 16.66 m⁻¹.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.7: Calculate the wavelength, frequency and wave number of a light wave whose period is 2.0 × 10⁻¹⁰ s.... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: What is the number of photons of light with a wavelength of 4000 pm that provide 1 J of energy?
questions.solutionContent:
Energy (E) of a photon = hν = hc/λ.
Energy (E_n) of ‘n’ photons = nhν = nhc/λ.
Given E_n = 1 J, λ = 4000 pm = 4000 × 10⁻¹² m, c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s, h = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js.
Rearranging for n: n = E_nλ / (hc).
Substituting values: n = (1 J × 4000 × 10⁻¹² m) / (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js × 3 × 10⁸ m/s) = 2.012 × 10¹⁶.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.8: What is the number of photons of light with a wavelength of 4000 pm that provide 1 J of energy?... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: A photon of wavelength 4 × 10⁻⁷ m strikes on metal surface, the work function of the metal being 2.13 eV. Calculate (i) the energy of the photon (eV), (ii) the kinetic energy of the emission, and (iii) the velocity of the photoelectron (1 eV= 1.6020 × 10⁻¹⁹ J).
questions.solutionContent:
(i) Energy (E) of a photon = hν = hc/λ.
h = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js, c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s, λ = 4 × 10⁻⁷ m.
E = (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js × 3 × 10⁸ m/s) / (4 × 10⁻⁷ m) = 4.97 × 10⁻¹⁹ J.
Converting to eV: E = (4.97 × 10⁻¹⁹ J) / (1.6020 × 10⁻¹⁹ J/eV) = 3.1020 eV.
(ii) The kinetic energy of emission E_k is given by E_k = E - W₀ (where W₀ is work function).
E_k = (3.1020 – 2.13) eV = 0.9720 eV.
(iii) The velocity of a photoelectron (v) can be calculated by E_k = ½ mv².
Converting E_k to Joules: 0.9720 eV × 1.6020 × 10⁻¹⁹ J/eV = 1.557 × 10⁻¹⁹ J.
v = √(2E_k / m), where m (mass of electron) = 9.11 × 10⁻³¹ kg.
v = √(2 × 1.557 × 10⁻¹⁹ J / 9.11 × 10⁻³¹ kg) = 5.84 × 10⁵ m s⁻¹.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.9: A photon of wavelength 4 × 10⁻⁷ m strikes on metal surface, the work function of the metal being 2.13 eV. Calculate (i) ... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: Electromagnetic radiation of wavelength 242 nm is just sufficient to ionise the sodium atom. Calculate the ionisation energy of sodium in kJ mol⁻¹.
questions.solutionContent:
Energy of sodium (E) = Nhc/λ, where N = Avogadro's number = 6.022 × 10²³ mol⁻¹.
λ = 242 nm = 242 × 10⁻⁹ m.
E = (6.022 × 10²³ mol⁻¹ × 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js × 3 × 10⁸ m/s) / (242 × 10⁻⁹ m).
E = 4.947 × 10⁵ J mol⁻¹ = 494.7 × 10³ J mol⁻¹ = 494 kJ mol⁻¹.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.10: Electromagnetic radiation of wavelength 242 nm is just sufficient to ionise the sodium atom. Calculate the ionisation en... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: A 25 watt bulb emits monochromatic yellow light of wavelength of 0.57μm. Calculate the rate of emission of quanta per second.
questions.solutionContent:
Power of bulb, P = 25 Watt = 25 Js⁻¹.
Energy of one photon, E = hν = hc/λ.
λ = 0.57 μm = 0.57 × 10⁻⁶ m.
E = (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js × 3 × 10⁸ m/s) / (0.57 × 10⁻⁶ m) = 34.87 × 10⁻²⁰ J.
Rate of emission of quanta per second = P/E = (25 Js⁻¹) / (34.87 × 10⁻²⁰ J) = 7.169 × 10¹⁹ s⁻¹.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.11: A 25 watt bulb emits monochromatic yellow light of wavelength of 0.57μm. Calculate the rate of emission of quanta per se... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: Electrons are emitted with zero velocity from a metal surface when it is exposed to radiation of wavelength 6800 Å. Calculate threshold frequency (ν₀) and work function (W₀) of the metal.
questions.solutionContent:
Threshold wavelength of radiation λ₀ = 6800 Å = 6800 × 10⁻¹⁰ m.
Threshold frequency ν₀ of the metal = c/λ₀ = (3 × 10⁸ m/s) / (6800 × 10⁻¹⁰ m) = 4.41 × 10¹⁴ s⁻¹.
Work function (W₀) of the metal = hν₀.
W₀ = (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js) × (4.41 × 10¹⁴ s⁻¹) = 2.922 × 10⁻¹⁹ J.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.12: Electrons are emitted with zero velocity from a metal surface when it is exposed to radiation of wavelength 6800 Å. Calc... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: What is the wavelength of light emitted when the electron in a hydrogen atom undergoes transition from an energy level with n = 4 to an energy level with n = 2?
questions.solutionContent:
The n_i = 4 to n_f = 2 transition will give rise to a spectral line of the Balmer series. The energy involved in the transition is given by the relation, E = -2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ J (1/n_f² - 1/n_i²).
Substituting the values: E = -2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ J (1/2² - 1/4²) = -2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ J (1/4 - 1/16) = -2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ J (3/16) = -4.0875 × 10⁻¹⁹ J.
The negative sign indicates the energy of emission.
Wavelength of light emitted λ = hc/
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.13: What is the wavelength of light emitted when the electron in a hydrogen atom undergoes transition from an energy level w... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: How much energy is required to ionise a H atom if the electron occupies n = 5 orbit? Compare your solution with the ionization enthalpy of H atom (energy required to remove the electron from n =1 orbit).
questions.solutionContent:
The expression of energy is given by, E_n = -2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ (Z²/n²) J.
For ionization from n₁ = 5 to n₂ = ∞ (where E_∞ = 0).
ΔE = E_∞ - E₅ = 0 - (-2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ (1²/5²)) J = 2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ / 25 J = 8.72 × 10⁻²⁰ J.
Energy required for ionization from n₁ = 1 to n₂ = ∞ is ΔE = E_∞ - E₁ = 0 - (-2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ (1²/1²)) J = 2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ J.
Hence, less energy is required to ionize an electron in the 5th orbital of hydrogen atom as compared to that in the ground state.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.14: How much energy is required to ionise a H atom if the electron occupies n = 5 orbit? Compare your solution with the ioni... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: What is the maximum number of emission lines when the excited electron of a H atom in n = 6 drops to the ground state?
questions.solutionContent:
The number of spectral lines produced when an electron in the nth level drops down to the ground state is given by n(n-1)/2.
Given, n = 6.
Number of spectral lines = 6 × (6-1)/2 = 6 × 5 / 2 = 15.
This can also be calculated as ∑(n₂ - n₁) = ∑(6-1) = ∑5 = 5+4+3+2+1 = 15.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.15: What is the maximum number of emission lines when the excited electron of a H atom in n = 6 drops to the ground state?... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: (i) The energy associated with the first orbit in the hydrogen atom is –2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ J atom⁻¹. What is the energy associated with the fifth orbit? (ii) Calculate the radius of Bohr’s fifth orbit for hydrogen atom.
questions.solutionContent:
(i) E_n = -2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ / n² J.
For the fifth orbit, n = 5, so E₅ = -2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ / 5² J = -2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ / 25 J = -8.72 × 10⁻²⁰ J.
(ii) For H atom, r_n = 0.529 × n² Å.
For the fifth orbit, n = 5, so r₅ = 0.529 × 5² Å = 0.529 × 25 Å = 13.225 Å = 1.3225 nm.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.16: (i) The energy associated with the first orbit in the hydrogen atom is –2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ J atom⁻¹. What is the energy associ... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: Calculate the wavenumber for the longest wavelength transition in the Balmer series of atomic hydrogen.
questions.solutionContent:
For the Balmer series, n₁ = 2. The wavenumber ṽ = R(1/n₁² - 1/n₂²).
For λ to be maximum (longest wavelength), ṽ should be minimum. This occurs when n₂ is minimum, which is n₂ = 3 for the Balmer series.
R = Rydberg constant = 1.097 × 10⁷ m⁻¹.
ṽ = (1.097 × 10⁷ m⁻¹) × (1/2² - 1/3²) = 1.097 × 10⁷ × (1/4 - 1/9) m⁻¹ = 1.097 × 10⁷ × (5/36) m⁻¹ = 1.523 × 10⁶ m⁻¹.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.17: Calculate the wavenumber for the longest wavelength transition in the Balmer series of atomic hydrogen.... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: What is the energy in joules, required to shift the electron of the hydrogen atom from the first Bohr orbit to the fifth Bohr orbit and what is the wavelength of the light emitted when the electron returns to the ground state? The ground state electron energy is –2.18 × 10⁻¹¹ ergs.
questions.solutionContent:
1 erg = 10⁻⁷ J.
Ground state electronic energy (E₁) = –2.18 × 10⁻¹¹ ergs. This means E_n = -2.18 × 10⁻¹¹ / n² ergs.
Energy required to shift from n=1 to n=5: ΔE = E₅ - E₁ = (-2.18 × 10⁻¹¹ / 5²) - (-2.18 × 10⁻¹¹ / 1²) ergs.
ΔE = 2.18 × 10⁻¹¹ (1/1² - 1/5²) = 2.18 × 10⁻¹¹ (1 - 1/25) = 2.18 × 10⁻¹¹ (24/25) = 2.09 × 10⁻¹¹ ergs.
Converting to Joules: ΔE = 2.09 × 10⁻¹¹ ergs × 10⁻⁷ J/erg = 2.09 × 10⁻¹⁸ J.
When the electron returns to ground state (n=1), energy emitted = 2.09 × 10⁻¹¹ ergs.
As E = hν = hc/λ, then λ = hc/E.
h = 6.626 × 10⁻²⁷ erg sec, c = 3.0 × 10¹⁰ cm s⁻¹.
λ = (6.626 × 10⁻²⁷ erg sec × 3.0 × 10¹⁰ cm s⁻¹) / (2.09 × 10⁻¹¹ ergs) = 9.51 × 10⁻⁶ cm = 951 Å.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.18: What is the energy in joules, required to shift the electron of the hydrogen atom from the first Bohr orbit to the fifth... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: The electron energy in hydrogen atom is given by E_n = (–2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸) / n² J. Calculate the energy required to remove an electron completely from the n = 2 orbit. What is the longest wavelength of light in cm that can be used to cause this transition?
questions.solutionContent:
Energy required to remove an electron completely from n=2 orbit (i.e., transition to n=∞):
ΔE = E_∞ - E₂ = 0 - (–2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ J atom⁻¹ / 2²) = 0 - (–2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸ / 4) J atom⁻¹ = 5.45 × 10⁻¹⁹ J atom⁻¹.
For the longest wavelength, the energy must be minimum, which corresponds to this exact ΔE.
ΔE = hν = hc/λ.
Rearranging for λ: λ = hc/ΔE.
h = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js, c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m s⁻¹.
λ = (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js × 3.0 × 10⁸ m s⁻¹) / (5.45 × 10⁻¹⁹ J) = 3.674 × 10⁻⁷ m = 3.674 × 10⁻⁵ cm.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.19: The electron energy in hydrogen atom is given by E_n = (–2.18 × 10⁻¹⁸) / n² J. Calculate the energy required to remove a... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: Calculate the wavelength of an electron moving with a velocity of 2.05 × 10⁷ ms⁻¹.
questions.solutionContent:
By de Broglie equation, λ = h/mv.
h = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js, m (mass of electron) = 9.11 × 10⁻³¹ kg, v = 2.05 × 10⁷ ms⁻¹.
λ = (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js) / (9.11 × 10⁻³¹ kg × 2.05 × 10⁷ ms⁻¹) = 3.55 × 10⁻¹¹ m.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.20: Calculate the wavelength of an electron moving with a velocity of 2.05 × 10⁷ ms⁻¹.... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: The mass of an electron is 9.11 × 10⁻³¹ kg. If its K.E. is 3.0 × 10⁻²⁵ J, calculate its wavelength.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.21: The mass of an electron is 9.11 × 10⁻³¹ kg. If its K.E. is 3.0 × 10⁻²⁵ J, calculate its wavelength.... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: Which of the following are isoelectronic species i.e., those having the same number of electrons? Na⁺, K⁺, Mg²⁺, Ca²⁺, S²⁻, Ar.
questions.solutionContent:
Isoelectronic species are those having the same number of electrons.
A positive charge means the shortage of an electron. A negative charge means gain of electron.
Number of electrons in Na⁺ = 11 - 1 = 10.
Number of electrons in K⁺ = 19 - 1 = 18.
Number of electrons in Mg²⁺ = 12 - 2 = 10.
Number of electrons in Ca²⁺ = 20 - 2 = 18.
Number of electrons in S²⁻ = 16 + 2 = 18.
Number of electrons in Ar = 18.
Hence, the following are isoelectronic species:
Na⁺ and Mg²⁺ (10 electrons each).
K⁺, Ca²⁺, S²⁻ and Ar (18 electrons each).
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.22: Which of the following are isoelectronic species i.e., those having the same number of electrons? Na⁺, K⁺, Mg²⁺, Ca²⁺, S... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: (i) Write the electronic configurations of the following ions: (a) H⁻ (b) Na⁺ (c) O²⁻ (d) F⁻ (ii) What are the atomic numbers of elements whose outermost electrons are represented by (a) 3s¹ (b) 2p³ and (c) 3p⁵? (iii) Which atoms are indicated by the following configurations? (a) [He]2s¹ (b) [Ne] 3s² 3p³ (c) [Ar] 4s² 3d¹.
questions.solutionContent:
(i) (a) ¹H = 1s¹. A negative charge means gain of electron.
∴ electronic configuration of H⁻ = 1s².
(b) ¹¹Na = 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s¹. A positive charge means the shortage of an electron.
∴ electronic configuration of Na⁺ = 1s² 2s² 2p⁶.
(c) ⁸O = 1s² 2s² 2p⁴.
∴ electronic configuration of O²⁻ = 1s² 2s² 2p⁶.
(d) ⁹F = 1s² 2s² 2p⁵.
∴ electronic configuration of F⁻ = 1s² 2s² 2p⁶.
(ii) (a) 3s¹: Completing the electron configuration as 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s¹.
Number of electrons = 2+2+6+1 = 11.
∴ Atomic number of the element = 11.
(b) 2p³: Completing the electron configuration as 1s² 2s² 2p³.
Number of electrons = 2+2+3 = 7.
∴ Atomic number of the element = 7.
(c) 3p⁵: Completing the electron configuration as 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁵.
Number of electrons = 2+2+6+2+5 = 17.
∴ Atomic number of the element = 17. (The source has 9, but based on the configuration it should be 17 for Chlorine).
(iii) (a) [He]2s¹: electronic configuration = 1s² 2s¹.
Atomic number = 2+1 = 3.
Hence, the element is Lithium (Li).
(b) [Ne] 3s² 3p³: electronic configuration = 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p³.
Atomic number = 2+2+6+2+3 = 15.
Hence, the element is Phosphorus (P).
(c) [Ar] 4s² 3d¹: electronic configuration = 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 4s² 3d¹.
Atomic number = 2+2+6+2+6+2+1 = 21.
Hence, the element is Scandium (Sc).
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.23: (i) Write the electronic configurations of the following ions: (a) H⁻ (b) Na⁺ (c) O²⁻ (d) F⁻ (ii) What are the atomic nu... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: What is the lowest value of n that allows g orbitals to exist?
questions.solutionContent:
For g-orbitals, the azimuthal quantum number (l) has a value of 4.
For any given principal quantum number 'n', the azimuthal quantum number (l) can have a value from 0 to (n-1).
Therefore, for l = 4, the minimum value of 'n' must be 5.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.24: What is the lowest value of n that allows g orbitals to exist?... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: An electron is in one of the 3d orbitals. Give the possible values of n, l and m_l for this electron.
questions.solutionContent:
For the 3d orbital:
The principal quantum number (n) = 3.
The azimuthal quantum number (l) = 2 (since d-orbitals correspond to l=2).
The magnetic quantum number (m_l) can have values from -l to +l. So for l=2, m_l can be -2, -1, 0, 1, 2.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.25: An electron is in one of the 3d orbitals. Give the possible values of n, l and m_l for this electron.... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: An atom of an element contains 29 electrons and 35 neutrons. Deduce (i) the number of protons and (ii) the electronic configuration of the element.
questions.solutionContent:
(i) For a neutral atom, the number of protons is equal to the number of electrons.
Therefore, the number of protons in the atom of the given element = 29, which is also its atomic number.
(ii) The electronic configuration of the atom with Z=29 (Copper) is 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 4s¹ 3d¹⁰.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.26: An atom of an element contains 29 electrons and 35 neutrons. Deduce (i) the number of protons and (ii) the electronic co... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: Give the number of electrons in the species H₂⁺, H₂ and O₂⁺.
questions.solutionContent:
H₂⁺: It has 2 protons (from two H atoms) but loses 1 electron, so 2 - 1 = 1 electron.
H₂: Each H atom has 1 electron, so H₂ has 1 + 1 = 2 electrons.
O₂⁺: An oxygen molecule (O₂) has 16 electrons (8 from each O atom). O₂⁺ means it has lost 1 electron, so 16 - 1 = 15 electrons.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.27: Give the number of electrons in the species H₂⁺, H₂ and O₂⁺.... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: (i) An atomic orbital has n = 3. What are the possible values of l and m_l? (ii) List the quantum numbers (m_l and l) of electrons for 3d orbital. (iii) Which of the following orbitals are possible? 1p, 2s, 2p and 3f.
questions.solutionContent:
(i) For a given value of n, l can have values from 0 to (n-1).
For n = 3, l = 0, 1, 2.
For a given value of l, m_l can have (2l+1) values.
When l = 0, m_l = 0.
When l = 1, m_l = -1, 0, 1.
When l = 2, m_l = -2, -1, 0, 1, 2.
(ii) For a 3d orbital, the principal quantum number (n) = 3 and azimuthal quantum number (l) = 2.
Therefore, for l = 2, the magnetic quantum number (m_l) values are -2, -1, 0, 1, 2.
(iii)1p is not possible because when n = 1, l can only be 0 (for s-orbital), but for a p-orbital, l must be 1.
2s is possible because when n = 2, l can be 0 or 1. For an s-orbital, l=0, which is allowed.
2p is possible because when n = 2, l can be 0 or 1. For a p-orbital, l=1, which is allowed.
3f is not possible because when n = 3, l can be 0, 1, or 2. For an f-orbital, l=3, which is not allowed for n=3.
questions.altText: NCERT Solutions Class 11 Chemistry - Structure of Atom - Q2.28: (i) An atomic orbital has n = 3. What are the possible values of l and m_l? (ii) List the quantum numbers (m_l and l) of... [Step-by-Step Solution]

questions.questionText: Using s, p, d notations, describe the orbital with the following quantum numbers. (a) n=1, l=0; (b) n=3; l=1 (c) n=4; l=2; (d) n=4; l=3.
questions.solutionContent:
(a) n=1, l=0 corresponds to 1s orbital.
(b) n=3, l=1 corresponds to 3p orbital.
(c) n=4, l=2 corresponds to 4d orbital.
(d) n=4, l=3 corresponds to 4f orbital.
